title: Subdomain takeover of ███
content:
Summary:
The subdomain ██████ had an CNAME record pointing to an unclaimed ███████ webservice. This is a high severity security issue because an attacker can register the subdomain on ███ and therefore can own the subdomain █████████.
Description:
The dangling CNAME record of █████████ is pointing to █████.███████ which was not claimed by you. I registered a service with this name and therefore was able to takeover the subdomain. Every attacker doing this has afterwards full control over the contents served on this subdomain.
Subdomain Affected:
██████████
Proof Of Concept:
I have uploaded a simple subdomain takeover PoC on http://███████/████████
Step-by-step Reproduction Instructions
Open ██████ and register for web app which is under market place. I have used ██████ (See: ████)
After registering, go to Custom Domains which will be available under settings. (See: ████)
In here, add custom domain i have used █████████ (See: █████)
After that upload any PoC you want to upload. I have used ████ which has my PoC. (See: ███████)
Suggested Mitigation/Remediation Actions
Remove the dangling CNAME record for █████
Claim it back in ███████ portal after I release it
Reference
Some hackerone reports #661751 #325336
NOTE:
I have claimed the subdomain http://█████████ at the current moment to keep it safe from malicious users. Whenever you want i will release ██████.███. Afterwards you can claim it back.
Impact
Subdomain takeover is abused for several purposes:
Malware distribution
Phishing / Spear phishing
XSS
steps: Identify a subdomain with a dangling CNAME record pointing to an unclaimed third-party service (e.g., using DNS enumeration tools).
Register the unclaimed service (e.g., on a cloud platform) using the same name as the CNAME target.
Configure the service to host malicious content or phishing pages.
Verify the subdomain now serves content from the newly registered service.
vuln_description: A subdomain takeover occurs when a subdomain's CNAME record points to an external service (e.g., a cloud provider) that is no longer claimed or configured. An attacker can register the unclaimed service, effectively gaining control over the subdomain and serving malicious content.
reason: The attack involves straightforward steps (DNS checks, service registration) and does not require deep understanding of complex interactions or novel logic. The primary challenge is identifying dangling CNAME records, which is a well-documented technique.

authnz_metadata.reason: The subdomain takeover vulnerability involves a dangling CNAME record pointing to an unclaimed service, which is not directly related to authentication or authorization bypass within the same application. The methodology described focuses on testing AuthN/AuthZ boundaries within a single application by swapping user sessions, actions, and resource IDs. Since this vulnerability is about DNS misconfiguration and external service registration, it falls outside the scope of the described methodologies.
